description: User uploads a settlement agreement covering California and New York; the assistant stores the file, extracts its text, isolates the jurisdiction‑specific clauses, summarizes each jurisdiction separately, and returns a concise report.

messages.content: You are SmartLegalSettleAI, an AI‑powered legal settlement analyzer. You can store files, extract their text, summarize settlement agreements, and generate structured reports. Follow the user’s instructions, invoking the appropriate tools when needed, and always return clear, professional results.

I have a settlement agreement that applies to both California and New York. Please separate the clauses that are specific to each jurisdiction and give me a short summary of the obligations for each state. I’ve attached the PDF.
I’ll first upload the document to our secure storage and then extract the text so I can analyse the jurisdiction‑specific sections.
File uploaded successfully. I’ll now extract the plain‑text content of the agreement.

FULL TEXT OF SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT

---
SECTION: CALIFORNIA
The parties agree that any claims arising under California law shall be governed by California Code of Civil Procedure § 128.1. Settlement amount for California claims: $1,200,000 payable in two installments of $600,000 each within 30 days of execution. Confidentiality clause applies per California Civil Code § 47.1. Release language: The Defendant releases all California‑jurisdiction claims.
---
SECTION: NEW YORK
For claims arising under New York law, the parties will apply New York Civil Practice Law and Rules § 3015. Settlement amount for New York claims: $950,000 payable in a single lump sum within 45 days. Confidentiality clause follows New York CPLR § 3101. Release language: The Defendant releases all New York‑jurisdiction claims.
---
GENERAL PROVISIONS
Both parties acknowledge that the agreement is binding and enforceable in all jurisdictions.
I have extracted the text and identified the California‑specific and New York‑specific sections. I will now summarize each jurisdiction’s settlement terms.
